abstract.text: The visual contents of the material property—a color, image, or source of animated content. Animatable.
A container for the color or texture of one of a material’s visual properties.
The visual contents of the material property—a color, image, or source of animated content. Animatable.
that modulates the effect of the material property. Animatable.

inlineContent.text: For details on each visual property and the ways their contents affect a material’s appearance, see
You can set a value for this property using any of the following types:
), specifying a uniform color for the material’s surface
), specifying a uniform scalar value for the material's surface (useful for physically based properties such as
), specifying a texture to be mapped across the material’s surface
object specifying the location of an image file
A specially formatted image or array of six images, specifying the faces of a cube map
When you examine elements of a scene loaded from a file, this value is always either a color object (of the
class, according to platform) or an image object (of the
class, according to platform). You can therefore use type introspection (the
matching in Swift) to determine the type of the material property’s contents.
In iOS 11, you may use an
object to preview live video from a capture device as a material property. In iOS 11, tvOS 11, and macOS 10.13, you may use an
object as a material property for video playback.

You may specify any Core Animation layer as the contents of a material property, such as a layer with an animated sublayer hierarchy. SceneKit cannot use a layer that is already being displayed elsewhere (for example, the backing layer of a
You can use the SpriteKit framework to provide static or animated content for a material property. SpriteKit provides options for generating and modifying texture images, such as the
method. You can also use an entire animated SpriteKit scene as the material property’s contents. When you use a
object as a material property’s contents, the
properties automatically update to match the corresponding features of the SpriteKit texture.
If the current content is a solid color, you can use explicit or implicit animations (see

) to change to another color, creating an effect that fades between the two colors. Using animations to change from or to other content types results in an instantaneous transition—for an animated transition between textured content types (or types that are themselves animated), create a shader modifier (see
SceneKit supports cube maps only for a material’s
property. You can provide a cube map in any of the ways described in
. Of these formats, the vertical strip provides the best performance, because it matches the memory layout SceneKit uses for rendering cube textures.
(pixel x/y positions map to latitude/longitude coordinates on a sphere)
